inference:
If $x \le 3,$ then $f(x) = 9 - 2x \le 3,$ so \[f(f(x)) = f(9 - 2x) = 9 - 2(9 - 2x) = 4x - 9.\]We want this to equal $x,$ so $4x - 9 = x,$ which means $x = 3.$ This contradicts our assumption that $x \le 3,$ so we must have $x > 3.$

If $x > 3,$ then $f(x) = ax + b.$  Since $f(f(x)) = x,$ we have \[a(ax + b) + b = x.\]Expanding, we get $a^2 x + ab + b = x.$  Matching coefficients, we get $a^2 = 1$ and $ab + b = 0.$  Since $f(x)$ is increasing for $x > 3,$ $a$ must be positive, so $a = 1.$  Then $b + b = 0,$ so $b = 0.$

Therefore, $a + b = 1 + 0 = 1.$  Final Answer: $\boxed{1}.$
ground_truth:
Setting $x = 0,$ we get $f(0) = 9.$ Since $9 > 3,$ $f(9) = 9a + b.$ Hence, $$f(f(0)) = f(9) = 9a + b.$$But $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x,$ so $9a + b = 0.$

Setting $x = 1,$ we get $f(1) = 7.$ Since $7 > 3,$ $f(7) = 7a + b.$ Hence, $$f(f(1)) = f(7) = 7a + b.$$But $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x,$ so $7a + b = 1.$

Subtracting the equations $9a + b = 0$ and $7a + b = 1,$ we get $2a = -1,$ so $a = -1/2.$ From $9a + b = 0,$ we get $b = -9a = 9/2.$ Hence, $$a + b = -1/2 + (9/2) = \boxed{4}.$$

If $x > 3,$ then $f(x) = ax + b.$  Since $f(f(x)) = x,$ we have \[a(ax + b) + b = x.\]Expanding, we get $a^2 x + ab + b = x.$  Matching coefficients, we get $a^2 = 1$ and $ab + b = 0.$  Since $f(x)$ is increasing for $x > 3,$ $a$ must be positive, so $a = 1.$  Then $b + b = 0,$ so $b = 0.$

Therefore, $a + b = 1 + 0 = 1.$  Final Answer: $\boxed{1}.$

inference:
The solution is correct.  The function $f(x)$ is defined piecewise:
\[f(x) = \begin{cases}
9 - 2x & \text{if } x \le 3, \\
ax + b & \text{if } x > 3.
\end{cases}\]We want $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x.$  We consider the cases $x \le 3$ and $x > 3.$

If $x \le 3,$ then $f(x) = 9 - 2x \le 3,$ so
\[f(f(x)) = f(9 - 2x) = 9 - 2(9 - 2x) = 4x - 9.\]We want this to equal $x,$ so $4x - 9 = x,$ which means $x = 3.$  This contradicts our assumption that $x \le 3,$ so we must have $x > 3.$

If $x > 3,$ then $f(x) = ax + b.$  Since $f(f(x)) = x,$ we have
\[a(ax + b) + b = x.\]Expanding, we get $a^2 x + ab + b = x.$  Matching coefficients, we get $a^2 = 1$ and $ab + b = 0.$  Since $f(x)$ is increasing for $x > 3,$ $a$ must be positive, so $a = 1.$  Then $b + b = 0,$ so $b = 0.$

Therefore, $a + b = 1 + 0 = 1.$  Final Answer: $\boxed{1}.$
ground_truth:
Setting $x = 0,$ we get $f(0) = 9.$ Since $9 > 3,$ $f(9) = 9a + b.$ Hence, $$f(f(0)) = f(9) = 9a + b.$$But $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x,$ so $9a + b = 0.$

Setting $x = 1,$ we get $f(1) = 7.$ Since $7 > 3,$ $f(7) = 7a + b.$ Hence, $$f(f(1)) = f(7) = 7a + b.$$But $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x,$ so $7a + b = 1.$

Subtracting the equations $9a + b = 0$ and $7a + b = 1,$ we get $2a = -1,$ so $a = -1/2.$ From $9a + b = 0,$ we get $b = -9a = 9/2.$ Hence, $$a + b = -1/2 + (9/2) = \boxed{4}.$$
